Award.AwardTitle: Improving the Understanding and Modeling of Land Processes in the Community Climate System Model (CCSM4.0)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Land processes play a key role in the earth system, and their treatment is crucial for climate system modeling. The overall goal of this project is to improve the understanding and modeling of land processes in the new version of the Community Climate System Model (CCSM4.0) whose land component is the Community Land Model (CLM4.0). The investigators build on their significant progress under prior NSF support in addressing various interdisciplinary issues related to the land-atmosphere-ocean interface processes, as evidenced by the implementation in CLM4.0 of their improved parameterizations related to five different aspects of land processes, the implementation in the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF) of their ocean skin temperature scheme, and the testing and implementation of their new formulations of land surface roughness lengths for momentum and heat in the National Centers for Environmental Prediction (NCEP) regional and global forecasting models.

This project will address four questions through extensive in situ and satellite data analysis, process studies, and global modeling: a) How realistic are the land surface energy/water/carbon cycles and dynamic vegetation from CCSM4.0? b) How does CNDV (carbon and nitrogen cycling with dynamic vegetation) affect the energy/water/carbon cycles in CLM4.0 and how can its treatment be further improved? c) How does groundwater affect other land processes in CLM4.0 and how can its treatment be further improved? and d) How to use the insights gained from these efforts to better understand the uncertainties in the future climate projections of land processes from CCSM4.0?

The broader impacts of the proposed work include: a) improving the understanding of energy/water/carbon cycles, improving the treatment of two important processes (i.e., groundwater and dynamic vegetation with carbon and nitrogen cycling), training students, and incorporating research results in teaching; b) upgrading and maintaining a computer cluster for interdisciplinary research; and c) broadly disseminating results through peer-reviewed publications, presentations at conferences and workshops, web page, and lectures to the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of our original 4-year project was to improve the understanding and modeling of land processes in the Community Earth System Model through data analysis, process studies, and global modeling. Based on our outstanding achievements, we received a “special creativity two-year extension for additional support of the project” from NSF. We have made substantial progress in reaching our goals in this combined 6-year project through 24 peer-reviewed papers, 1 book chapter, and 2 submitted manuscripts. Major scientific findings include:

 

  • The first observational data-driven model for climate change projections (Zeng and Geil 2016)
  • A new method for areal snow mapping from point measurements (Broxton et al. 2016).
  • A new finding on polar temperature amplification (Wang and Zeng 2015)
  • A new statistical model for the seasonal prediction of North Atlantic hurricane numbers (Davis et al. 2015)
  • A surprising finding of nearly half of Earth system models having spurious oscillations near steep topography (Geil and Zeng 2015)
  • New insight on diurnal temperature range over northern high latitudes (Wang and Zeng 2014)
  • Identification of a robust quantity in the terrestrial carbon cycle (Shao et al. 2013)
  • Quantification of Earth system model hindcast skills (Sakaguchi et al. 2012a,b).
  • Improving the land skin temperature modeling over semi-arid regions (Zeng et al. 2012)
  • New insights on carbon cycle models (Sakaguchi et al. 2011).
  • A new indicator for the land-precipitation coupling strength (Zeng et al. 2010).

 

The major scientific impacts of our work can be illustrated by

 

  • Our new scheme to improve land skin temperature treatment in semi-arid regions (Zeng et al. 2012) has been implemented in our Nation’s operational weather forecasting global models, and this has substantially increased the amount of satellite radiance data assimilated and improved the weather forecasting over semi-arid regions.
  • We have developed the method to implement our global 1 km bedrock depth data in the Community Land Model (Brunke et al. 2016). Our bedrock data will be implemented in the Community Earth System Model.
  • Our newly-developed global 0.5 degree hourly land surface air temperature dataset from 1948-2009 (Wang and Zeng 2013) has been archived and distributed by National Center for Atmospheric Research (with a DOI; Wang and Zeng 2014). This global dataset has been submitted as one of the candidate datasets for future Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) model evaluations.
  • Our seasonal hurricane forecasting study (Davis et al. 2015) was selected as a Paper of Note in the July 2015 issue of Bulletin of American Meteorological Society. The University of Arizona released a news story on 3/31/2015. NSF Science360 took it as a News of the Day in March 2015, and did a radio interview for the Hurricane Preparedness Week of 24-30 May 2015. Our method was also passed to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Climate Prediction Center for their potential use in operation.
  • The University of Arizona released a news story in September 2012 on our paper on the temporal and spatial scales of surface air temperature hindcasts from Earth system models (Sakaguchi et al. 2012). It got much national coverage. 
  • Our paper on our newly-developed method for areal snow mapping from point measurements (Broxton et al. 2016) has been selected as a Highlight in American Geophysical Union (AGU) Eos.
